Award.AwardTitle: Studies in moduli theory and birational geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abramovich will continue studying problems in moduli theory; the main focus of the project is moduli spaces of stable logarithmic maps and associated Gromov-Witten theory. Additional topics include deformations of wild p-covers, and problems which also bear on birational geometry of varieties, including the study of pseudoideals as differential graded schemes, and the tropicalization of moduli space.

The area of study of this project lies within algebraic geometry, the branch of mathematics devoted to geometric shapes called algebraic varieties, defined by polynomial equations. Algebraic geometry has significant applications in coding, industrial control, and computation. But the topics of this project are more closely related to applications in theoretical physics, where physicists consider algebraic varieties as a piece of the fine structure of our universe. This is especially true with the first topic, moduli theory. This theory studies a remarkable phenomenon in which the collection of all algebraic varieties of the same type is often manifested as an algebraic variety, called a moduli space, in its own right. Thus in algebraic geometry, the metaphor of thinking about a community of "organisms" as itself being an "organism" is not just a metaphor but a rigorous and quite useful fact. The other topic studied in this project is birational geometry, which is devoted to a certain abstract relationship, called birational equivalence, among algebraic varieties, which lies at the foundation of algebraic geometry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Moduli spaces were a central object of investigation in this project, and the majority of outcomes were concerned with moduli spaces.

There is a remarkable phenomenon in geometry, in which the collection of all geometric shapes (curves, surfaces, manifolds, varieties)  of the same type is manifested by a geometric shape of a similar nature, called a moduli space. Thus in geometry the metaphor of thinking about a community of "organisms" as itself being an "organism" is not just a metaphor but a rigorous and quite useful fact. This is especially true in algebraic geometry, which is the natural home for moduli spaces; one aspect of this project was to investigate a similar phenomenon in a relatively new subject called Tropical Geometry, and study a tantalizing parallelism between algebraic and tropical geometry.

In the first attached diagram we see the pattern by which algebraic curves of genus 2 degenerate. In the second figure we see the the pattern by which tropical curves of genus 2 degenerate - which goes in precisely the opposite direction. This phenomenon was investigated in detail in a paper with Caporaso and Payne due to appear. A less technical exposition is provided in a separate published paper, and a further study and deep general results provided in Ulirsch's thesis. All these outcomes were funded in part by this project.

Moduli spaces are a key area of contact between algebraic geometry and mathematical physics. Moduli spaces serve as a foundational tool for Gromov-Witten theory, which itself serves as a mathematical underpinning for one aspect of string theory and especially mirror symmetry. The main effort in this project was devoted to the study of logarithmic Gromov-Witten theory, a relatively new and promising aspect of Gromov-Witten theory. A number of foundational results were proven, and progress was made towards the goal of a general logarithmic degeneration formula, part of the Gross-Siebert program for mirror symmetry.

As for broader impact, three PhD theses were written with funding from this award, by S. Molcho (2014), E. Routis and M. Ulirsch (2015), and an undergraduate thesis was written by J. Semonsen (2015). In addition two visiting PhD students were advised during this period, and two expository research articles were written - one published and one due to appear, and the PI has continued his work in conference organizing.
